title: Blockchain Basics Challenges
description: Interactive drag-and-drop challenges for blockchain fundamentals with comprehensive explanations

educational.title: Understanding Block and Transaction
educational.explanation: This challenge focuses on core blockchain concepts. Block and Transaction are fundamental building blocks that make blockchain technology secure and decentralized.
keyPoints: Block: Essential component for blockchain functionality
Transaction: Works together with Block to maintain security
Hash: A key feature that distinguishes blockchain from traditional systems

detailedLearning.whatYourelearning: The foundational elements that make blockchain possible - blocks store transactions, and hashes ensure security.

Block.definition: A container that holds a collection of valid transactions
Block.purpose: Groups transactions together for efficient processing and verification
Block.analogy: Like a page in a ledger book that contains multiple entries

Transaction.definition: A record of value transfer between blockchain addresses
Transaction.purpose: Represents the movement of digital assets or data
Transaction.analogy: Like writing a check - it records who sent what to whom

Hash.definition: A unique digital fingerprint created from block data
Hash.purpose: Ensures data integrity and creates the chain linkage
Hash.analogy: Like a tamper-evident seal that changes if anything inside is modified

detailedLearning.practicalApplication: When you send cryptocurrency, your transaction gets bundled into a block with other transactions. The block is then sealed with a hash and added to the blockchain.

challenges.title: Consensus Mechanism Matching
challenges.description: Match consensus mechanisms with their characteristics

educational.title: Blockchain Consensus Mechanisms
educational.explanation: Consensus mechanisms are the methods blockchain networks use to agree on the validity of transactions and maintain network security.
keyPoints: Proof of Work: Uses computational power to secure the network
Proof of Stake: Uses economic stake as security mechanism
Delegated Proof of Stake: Combines efficiency with democratic selection

detailedLearning.whatYourelearning: How blockchain networks reach agreement without a central authority.

Proof of Work.definition: Miners compete to solve complex mathematical puzzles
Proof of Work.example: Bitcoin miners race to find the right number that makes a valid block

Proof of Stake.definition: Validators are chosen based on their stake in the network
Proof of Stake.example: Ethereum 2.0 validators lock up ETH to participate in consensus

Delegated Proof of Stake.definition: Token holders vote for delegates who validate transactions
Delegated Proof of Stake.cons: More centralized, requires active community participation
Delegated Proof of Stake.example: EOS token holders vote for 21 block producers
